pageData.text: Earthquakes are vibrations that occur naturally inside the earth due to ruptures, volcanic eruptions, or mass movements. The vibrations radiate outward as , which are detected at seismic stations and recorded in . Seismograms can be used to determine the location of an earthquake’s and the magnitude of the earthquake. In this investigation, students will learn how to read a seismogram and use it to locate an earthquake’s epicenter, determine when it happened, and measure its strength.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 15 minutes 
Activity 1: Modeling Earthquakes – 35 minutes 
Activity 2: Plotting Earthquakes – 40 minutes 
Activity 3: Reading Seismograms – 50 minutes

text: Identify and explain how <button class='glossary-text'>faults</button>, volcanic eruptions, and mass movements can cause earthquakes.
Interpret a and travel-time graph to determine the location of an earthquake’s .
Determine the magnitude of an earthquake by interpreting seismogram data.

pageData.text: The Yellowstone caldera, also called the Yellowstone supervolcano, is located under Yellowstone National Park in the northwestern United States. The caldera measures 43 by 28 miles (70 by 45 kilometers). Volcanologists estimate that the Yellowstone supervolcano erupts every 600,000 to 800,000 years, with the last eruption taking place approximately 640,000 years ago.

Yellowstone National Park averages 1,000-3,000 earthquakes a year. Although many of these eruptions are below a magnitude of 3, researchers think that the Yellowstone supervolcano might wake up soon (geologically speaking). An increase in earthquakes throughout the park indicates the possibility that fresh magma has recently been fed into the Yellowstone caldera reservoir. Volcanologists estimate that the next supervolcano eruption will occur in about 70,000 years. After each Yellowstone supervolcano eruption, volcanic debris covered much of the continental United States, and the next eruption will be no different.

Samson, A. (27 September 2022). When a Sleeping Giant Awakes. National Geographic.
https://education.nationalgeographic.org/resource/when-sleeping-giant-awakes/

Yellowstone satellite map by http://www.terraprints.com is available under CC BY 2.5 at
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Yellowstone_satellite_map.jpg

pageData.altText: Yellowstone National Park as seen from a satellite.

pageData.text: The earth is not a solid piece of material; it is made up (Figure 1). There are seven primary plates that are comprised of the crust and mantle which collectively are deemed the . Even when you sit as still as possible you are on top of a plate that is slowly moving. This is because the lithosphere is situated on top of the highly viscous .

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A world map showing the names and regions of the tectonic plates on Earth.

pageData.text: Plate boundaries are locations where plates meet. Geologists classify these plate boundaries depending on how they move (Figure 2). When plates move away from each other, they are known as . These plate boundaries are common in seafloor spreading. When plates slide past each other, the boundary is known as a . When these plates move and rub against each other, geologist’s call the boundary . Volcanoes and mountains are known to be formed as a result of plates bumping against each other. When tension is released from these types of plate boundaries, energy is also released. The energy that is released is known as an earthquake. , or the study of earthquakes, has been around for thousands of years. Earthquakes are a common occurrence; over one million happen each year, with most going unnoticed or detected only by sensitive equipment. Despite the destruction they create, earthquakes play a role in mountain building and continental drift as well.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram showing the three types of plate boundaries: divergent plate boundary, transform plate boundary, and convergent plate boundary.

pageData.subTitle: What causes Earthquakes?
pageData.text: (scientists that study earthquakes) have learned there are many different triggers for earthquakes. Some of these include a sudden modification or a new that has been generated, volcanic activity, landslides, and anthropogenic activities (i.e. oil drilling).

pageData.subTitle: Types of Faults
pageData.text: Normal faults (Figure 3) are fractures in the Earth's crust that are produced as the land stretches or elongates. In normal faults, the (above the fault) slides down the with gravity. (Figure 3) are created as the crust is packed tightly together. The result of the reverse fault is the opposite of the normal fault because the hanging wall moves upwards relative to the foot wall. These faults are commonly found in collisional mountain belts. A is similar to a reverse fault but is not as steep. A reverse fault might have a 60˚ slope and a thrust fault may have a 30˚ slope, for example. (Figure 3) are generally vertical in nature but cause no rearrangement between the blocks. are termed as such because they have been observed moving or there is evidence of seismic activity during the last 10,000 years. are the opposite of active faults because they have not moved in many years and might not ever move again. However, even if a fault has not moved in a million years, it is possible that will become reactivated.

The <button class='glossary-text'>elastic rebound theory</button> states that rock on each side of the fault is always moving. Stress then increases and thus potential energy builds up. Rocks also become deformed from the constant friction against them. At a certain point, the strain will exceed the locking of the two masses and result in a release of energy as the two rocks return to a state of less stress.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Diagram showing normal fault, Diagram showing reverse fault, Diagram showing strike-slip fault

pageData.question: The elastic rebound theory says which of the following is true?

options.text: Rock on each side of the fault is always moving.
Rock only moves on a reverse fault.
Rock surrounding a fault only moves if the fault is active.
Faults have a have a 60° slope.
Faults have a have a 30° slope.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The elastic rebound theory states that rock on each side of the fault is always moving.

pageData.question: A fault that has moved in recent geologic history is considered which of the following?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Active faults are termed as such because they have recently shifted or will move in the near future. Generally, active faults have been observed moving or there is evidence of seismic activity during the last 10,000 years.

pageData.subTitle: Earthquake Anatomy
pageData.text: are quakes that occur prior to the main quake. Sometimes they precede the earthquake by a few days, but can also precede them by years. The or is the location beneath the earth’s surface where the energy was released from the plates colliding and releasing energy (Figure 4). The is the location on the earth’s surface directly above the hypocenter (Figure 4). follow the main shock and can be felt in the same place as the main earthquake. Aftershocks are usually weaker than the earthquake but sometimes the aftershocks can surpass the main quake’s magnitude.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Cross section of the Earth’s crust, with labels for the hypocenter (bottom layer), epicenter (middle, directly above the hypocenter), and the fault plane (top region).

pageData.text: are the vibrations from the energy released during an earthquake. There are two that are produced by earthquakes: , or and , or (Figure 5). P-waves travel faster than S-waves and are the first to be measured at a in a lab. P-waves also travel through all substances. In contrast, S-waves cannot travel through gases and liquids because gases and liquids will not return to their original shapes after the wave has traveled through it. S-waves usually have a higher amplitude (peak height) than P-waves. P-waves can alter the volume of substances when traveling through them, while S-waves change the shape of substances. are “shaking” waves and are the waves most associated with the movement of the ground. These waves usually have the greatest amplitude and cause more destruction than other waves.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Diagram showing the two types of body waves that earthquakes produce: P waves and S waves.

pageData.subTitle: Measuring Earthquakes
pageData.text: A uses a to determine seismic activity (Figure 6). The general idea of how they work is that a weight is hanging freely but tethered securely to the bedrock.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: A diagram of a seismograph. A heavy weight is suspended from a spring over the solid base. A pen hangs from the weight and a rotating drum with paper sits below it on the base.

pageData.text: When an earthquake occurs, the weight is held still due to the properties of inertia, but the base and the earth move. A pen at the bottom of the weight records the vibrations. The recording from a seismograph is called a (Figure 7). is a method utilized by seismologists to pinpoint the location of the of an earthquake.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: A seismograph with P-waves, S-waves, and surface waves labled.

pageData.text: Scientists gather from at least 3 different seismic stations and analyze the arrival times of the and . On a map, a geologist would draw a circle around the stations based on its distance away from the earthquake’s . The epicenter is where the circles intersect (Figure 8).

pageData.altText: Figure 8: A map of the U.S. with 3 data points on the west coast, which represent 3 seismic stations. Each data point is surrounded by a circle; where the 3 circles intersect is the epicenter, which is marked by a star on the map.

pageData.subTitle: Modified Mercalli Intensity Scale
pageData.text: The measures earthquakes on 12 severity levels. To determine the magnitude of an earthquake, glean data from seismic records to estimate the amount of energy released from an earthquake. This scale primarily looks at damage that was done (Table 1). As the levels increase, the damage becomes worse. For example, the vibration intensity of the first level (I) is only felt by certain people in favorable circumstances. On the other extreme, an earthquake that measured XII (12) would cause complete destruction, with bridges being decimated, and people reporting seeing the ground move like an ocean wave. Magnitude is more accurately measured for larger earthquakes.

tableData.text: Not felt except by a very few under especially favorable conditions.
Felt only by a few persons at rest, especially on upper floors of buildings.

Felt quite noticeably by persons indoors, especially on upper floors of buildings. Many people do not recognize it as an earthquake. Standing motor cars may rock slightly. Vibrations similar to the passing of a truck. Duration estimated.

Felt indoors by many, outdoors by few during the day. At night, some awakened. Dishes, windows, doors disturbed; walls make cracking sound. Sensation like heavy truck striking building. Standing motor cars rocked noticeably.
Felt by nearly everyone; many awakened. Some dishes, windows broken. Unstable objects overturned. Pendulum clocks may stop.
Felt by all, many frightened. Some heavy furniture moved; a few instances of fallen plaster. Damage slight.

Damage negligible in buildings of good design and construction; slight to moderate in well-built ordinary structures; considerable damage in poorly built or badly designed structures; some chimneys broken.

Damage slight in specially designed structures; considerable damage in ordinary substantial buildings with partial collapse. Damage great in poorly built structures. Fall of chimneys, factory stacks, columns, monuments, walls. Heavy furniture overturned.

Damage considerable in specially designed structures; well-designed frame structures thrown out of plumb. Damage great in substantial buildings, with partial collapse. Buildings shifted off foundations.
Some well-built wooden structures destroyed; most masonry and frame structures destroyed with foundations. Rails bent.
Few, if any (masonry) structures remain standing. Bridges destroyed. Rails bent greatly.
Damage total. Lines of sight and level are distorted. Objects thrown into the air.

pageData.subTitle: Richter scale
pageData.text: The equates an earthquake’s magnitude based on the maximum wave amplitude (). Amplitude is directly associated with the amount of ground movement during an earthquake. A uses a to determine the size and timing of the biggest wave and then plots it on the Richter scale. The earthquake’s number is based on the magnitude and takes into consideration the distance between the station and the . The Richter scale is a good way to measure small quakes, but inadequate to measure larger, stronger quakes. If you know the amplitude of the highest and the S-P time (the difference in time between the arrival of the and the ), then the magnitude can be calculated. Using an earthquake nomogram (Figure 9), the magnitude can be determined by plotting the distance (km) or S-P time (seconds) on the first column in Figure 9 and the amplitude (mm) on the last column in Figure 9. By lining up the data points from these two columns, the two points will intersect in the middle column. This value is the magnitude of the event.

pageData.altText: Figure 9: An earthquake nomogram, which shows 3 columns of data: the left column marks the distance (km) and the S-P time (seconds). The right column marks the amplitude (mm). The middle column is the intersection in which the 2 points meet, which marks the magnitude of the event.

tableData.text: Often felt, but rarely causes damage
Noticeable shaking of indoor items, rattling noises. Significant damage unlikely.
Can cause major damage to poorly constructed buildings over small regions. At most slight damage to well-designed buildings.
Can be destructive in areas up to about 160 km (99 mi) across in populated areas
Can cause serious damage over larger areas
Can cause serious damage in areas several hundred km across
Devastating in areas several thousand km across
Never recorded; widespread devastation across very large areas

pageData.text: The (Table 3) was introduced to measure larger and stronger earthquakes more efficiently than the . It measures all the energy released on the entire surface. This method of measurement takes into account fault slippage, the size of the surface, and the composition of the materials that were involved in the fault. have been able to go back and measure prior earthquakes using this scale and give those quakes a more accurate reading.

tableData.text: Considerable to serious damage to buildings; railroad tracks bent
Felt by all, with slight building damage
Felt by some to felt by many

pageData.question: Which of the following scales was introduced to measure larger and stronger earthquakes more efficiently than the Richter scale?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The Moment Magnitude Scale was introduced to measure larger and stronger earthquakes more efficiently than the Richter scale.

pageData.question: How often are great earthquakes (Moment Magnitude 8.0+) predicted to occur?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Great earthquakes can completely destroy communities near the epicenter and are predicted to occur yearly.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The Moment Magnitude Scale measures all the energy released on the entire fault surface. This method of measurement takes into account fault slippage, the size of the surface, and the composition of the materials that were involved in the fault. Seismologists have been able to go back and measure prior earthquakes using this scale and give those quakes a more accurate reading.

tableData.text: Considerable to serious damage to buildings; railroad tracks bent
Felt by all, with slight building damage
Felt by some to felt by many

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for activities 1 and 2 of this investigation. Before beginning, you will download Google Earth Pro. In activity 1, you will cut and tape sandpaper strips to form the bottom plate. Then, you will assemble cardboard, sandpaper and rubber bands to form the top plate. Next, you will set up the sandpaper tectonic plates. Then, you will pull the top plate along the bottom plate and observe their interaction. Next, you will add washers to the top plate and observe the movement. Then, you will measure how far the rubber bands can stretch before the plate moves. You will repeat this for 4 trials and test 0, 8 and 16 washers on top of the top plate. In activity 2, you will print out the earthquake data points and world map. Then, you will plot the earthquakes onto the map and photograph it. Next, you will open the IRIS earthquake browser and generate a map of earthquakes. Finally, you will compare the maps before proceeding to activity 3.

A map of the procedural workflow for activity 3 of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, you will identify the P and S waves on a seismogram and calculate the S-P time. Then, you will print out the nomogram, mark the S-P time and amplitude, and connect the lines. Next, you will determine the magnitude of the earthquake. Then, you will open Google Earth Pro and search for a city from a given list. Next, you will use the ruler tool and the given data to approximate the location of the epicenter of the earthquake. Once you have done this for all cities listed, triangulate the latitude and longitude of the earthquake’s epicenter.

Wear your goggles while performing
Activity 1: Modeling Earthquakes.

Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) described in the Safety and Activity sections.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Seafloor spreading is an example of which of the following?
Which of these describes a transform plate boundary?

options.text: plates moving away from each other
fractures in the earth's crust produced by stretching of the land

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a positive role that earthquakes play in the environment?
Which of the following has NOT been identified by seismologists as a trigger for earthquakes?
Which of these types of faults is produced as the land stretches?
Which of these faults occur when the hanging wall moves upwards relative to the footwall as the crust is packed tightly together?
Which of the following is the location beneath the earth's surface where the energy is released from the plates colliding in an earthquake?
Which of the following is the location on the earth's surface directly above the hypocenter?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the Activities.
Obtain all materials.
Clear a workspace approximately 3 ft long.
If you have not already, download Google Earth Pro.
Accept the agreement and download the program. You can open Google Earth Pro from the desktop after installation.

In Activity 1, you will create two <button class='glossary-text'>tectonic plates</button> out of sandpaper and pull one across the other via a rubber band to model plate movement. You will then observe how far the rubber band can be stretched before the plate moves with various numbers of washers on top of it.
Take one sheet of sandpaper and cut it in half along the more narrow edge. Each sheet is 9 × 11", so there should be two 4½ × 11" strips after cutting.

Tape the strips, coarse side up, to a hard surface lengthwise to form one 4½ × 22" strip. Be sure to place the tape around the outer edges to leave as much of the sandpaper exposed as possible as seen in Figure 10.

pageData.altText: Figure 10: Two rectangular pieces of sandpaper (coarse side up) taped together to form a 4.5 x 22” strip. All outer edges and corners are taped down onto a level surface.

pageData.text: Across the long edge of the piece of cardboard, cut a strip 4" wide, creating a 4 × 8½" piece of cardboard.
Cut a piece of sandpaper 3½ × 7½" (slightly smaller is ok but no bigger) and tape it to one side of the cardboard as shown in Figure 11. Be sure to leave as much sandpaper exposed as possible.

pageData.altText: Figure 11: A rectangular piece of coarse sandpaper taped on top of a slightly larger piece of cardboard. On the left side of the cardboard there is a hole punched with a rubber band looped through it.

pageData.text: With scissors, punch a hole at one end of the cardboard. Tie one rubber band into the hole. Tie another rubber band to the end of the first one, as seen in Figure 12, to create a chain of 2 rubber bands.

pageData.altText: Figure 12: Close-up view of a piece of carboard with a small hole punched in the middle. There is a rubber band tied though the hole, with a second one tied to it, forming a chain.

pageData.text: Place the cardboard, sandpaper side down, on top of the sandpaper taped to the work surface. This will represent two <button class='glossary-text'>tectonic plates</button> and the forces of friction between them. The rubber bands represent the direction the plate is trying to move.
Pull the cardboard by the rubber band closely and parallel to the table surface and observe its movement.
Add 8 washers to the top of the cardboard as seen in Figure 13. Pull the rubber band again and observe its movement.

pageData.altText: Figure 13: A rectangular piece of sandpaper and a slightly smaller piece of cardboard, both taped to a flat surface. The piece of cardboard is on the right side, slightly overlapping the sandpaper. There are 8 washers stacked on top of the carboard. There is also a small hole punched through the cardboard with a thick rubber band looped through; a second, thinner rubber band is looped through the thick one.

pageData.text: Reset the model and place a ruler near the end of the rubber band as seen in Figure 14. This will be used to measure how far the rubber band is stretched before the "plate" moves.

pageData.altText: Figure 14: A rectangular piece of sandpaper and a slightly smaller piece of cardboard, both taped to a flat surface. The piece of cardboard is on the right side, slightly overlapping the sandpaper. There are 8 washers stacked on top of the carboard. There is also a small hole punched through the cardboard with a thick rubber band looped through; a second, thinner rubber band is looped through the thick one. A 12” plastic ruler is resting directly above the sandpaper.

pageData.text: Pull the rubber band and record the distance (in inches) it stretched before the plate moved in Data Table 1 and record any observations on the movement of the washers. Repeat for 4 trials with 8 washers.
Remove the 8 washers and reset the model. Record the distance the rubber band stretches when pulled in Data Table 1 for 4 trials without washers.

Reset the model and add all 16 washers back on the "plate." Pull the rubber band and record the distance the rubber band stretched before the plate moved in Data Table 1. Also record any observations on the movement of the washers. Repeat for 4 trials with 16 washers.
In Activity 2, you will plot the earthquake data by hand on a map. You will then use a computer to generate the same map and compare the two maps.

typeBefore.text: In Part A of this activity, you will use a set of data to plot the earthquakes of magnitude 5 or greater that occurred during a given one-month period. In Part B, you will use a computer to plot earthquake data for a six-month period.

pageData.text: If you have not already, print the set of Earthquake Data Points and the World Map worksheet.

Using the longitude and latitude coordinates on the Earthquake Data Points sheets, plot the point where each earthquake occurred on the World Map worksheet. Positive values of longitude are East and negative values are West. Positive values of latitude are North and negative are South.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take a photograph of your map.
Use a computer to generate a map of the earthquakes that occurred worldwide during the period from January 1, 2005 through July 1, 2005. To do this:

text: First access the IRIS Earthquake Browser.

pageData.text: Once you have accessed the IRIS Earthquake Browser global earthquake search site, perform a global search with the following parameters:

a. Time Range:
  • Uncheck “Earliest Available” and “Latest Available”.
  • In the top date, enter “2005-01-01”.
  • In the lower date, enter “2005-07-01”.
b. Magnitude Range:
  • Uncheck “All Values”.
  • Magnitude: Minimum = 5, Maximum = 9
Compare your map of data points for one month to the computer-generated map of the entire six-month period.

In Activity 3, you will use a nomograph to calculate the S-P time and magnitude of an earthquake. You will then use Google Earth Pro and provided data to find the latitude and longitude of the <button class='glossary-text'>epicenters</button> of various earthquakes.

typeBefore.text: Geologists can gather a lot of data from <button class='glossary-text'>seismogram</button> recordings. In this activity, you will analyze seismograms to glean more data about an earthquake’s location and magnitude.

pageData.text: Identify the , , and on the seismogram in Figure 15.
How much time elapsed between the first P- and S-waves? Subtract the time of the first P-wave from the time of the first S-wave.
If you have not already done so, print out the nomogram (Figure 16).
Mark the S-P time (calculated in Step 2) on the nomogram. What is the corresponding distance from the ?
The earthquake had an amplitude of 7 millimeters. Mark the amplitude on the right side of the nomogram.
With the ruler and a pen, draw a straight line between the two points, from distance to amplitude. The magnitude of the earthquake is where the line crosses the center column.
Open Google Earth Pro.
Search for Palmer, Alaska in the search box.
In the “Tools” menu, select “Ruler,” and then select the “Circle” tab, and make sure the dropdown menu next to radius is in miles.
Look at Table 4 to determine the distance from the epicenter for Palmer, Alaska.

At any point in Palmer, Alaska, click (with the “Ruler” window still open) on the square that appears on your screen. Note: You may have to click and drag the “Ruler” window to the side to see the city on the map.

Then move the mouse pointer outwards (physically move your hand; scrolling will not work) until the radius in the “Ruler” window is the same as the distance in Table 4. Click on the map again to hold the circle at this position. Note: You may need to zoom out after the initial click in this step (using the scroller on the mouse) to get the full range of the circle.
Click “Save” in the “Ruler” window. In the “New Path” window that opens, change the name to “Palmer, Alaska” and click “OK.” This circle will now remain on the map.
Repeat steps 2–6 for the locations of Golden, Colorado and Bogota, Colombia.

Hover your mouse cursor over the point closest to where the 3 circles intersect. The circles may not meet exactly at a single point. Record the latitude and longitude of the intersection in the Lab Notebook. Note: You may need to click on the “Tour Guide” and minimize it to see the latitude and longitude in the lower right portion of Google Earth.
Rinse and dry the lab equipment and return the materials to the equipment kit.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A world map showing the names and regions of the tectonic plates on Earth.
Figure 2: Diagram showing the three types of plate boundaries: divergent plate boundary, transform plate boundary, and convergent plate boundary.
Figure 3: Diagram showing normal fault, Diagram showing reverse fault, Diagram showing strike-slip fault

pageData.content: Figure 4.  Relative locations of epicenter and hypocenter on a fault plane
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Cross section of the Earth’s crust, with labels for the hypocenter (bottom layer), epicenter (middle, directly above the hypocenter), and the fault plane (top region).
Figure 5: Diagram showing the two types of body waves that earthquakes produce: P waves and S waves.
Figure 6: A diagram of a seismograph. A heavy weight is suspended from a spring over the solid base. A pen hangs from the weight and a rotating drum with paper sits below it on the base.
Figure 7: A seismograph with P-waves, S-waves, and surface waves labled.

Figure 8: A map of the U.S. with 3 data points on the west coast, which represent 3 seismic stations. Each data point is surrounded by a circle; where the 3 circles intersect is the epicenter, which is marked by a star on the map.

pageData.content: Table 1. The Modified Mercalli Intensity Scale
pageData.title: Table 1.

tableData.text: Not felt except by a very few under especially favorable conditions.
Felt only by a few persons at rest, especially on upper floors of buildings.

Felt quite noticeably by persons indoors, especially on upper floors of buildings. Many people do not recognize it as an earthquake. Standing motor cars may rock slightly. Vibrations similar to the passing of a truck. Duration estimated.

Felt indoors by many, outdoors by few during the day. At night, some awakened. Dishes, windows, doors disturbed; walls make cracking sound. Sensation like heavy truck striking building. Standing motor cars rocked noticeably.
Felt by nearly everyone; many awakened. Some dishes, windows broken. Unstable objects overturned. Pendulum clocks may stop.
Felt by all, many frightened. Some heavy furniture moved; a few instances of fallen plaster. Damage slight.

Damage negligible in buildings of good design and construction; slight to moderate in well-built ordinary structures; considerable damage in poorly built or badly designed structures; some chimneys broken.

Damage slight in specially designed structures; considerable damage in ordinary substantial buildings with partial collapse. Damage great in poorly built structures. Fall of chimneys, factory stacks, columns, monuments, walls. Heavy furniture overturned.

Damage considerable in specially designed structures; well-designed frame structures thrown out of plumb. Damage great in substantial buildings, with partial collapse. Buildings shifted off foundations.
Some well-built wooden structures destroyed; most masonry and frame structures destroyed with foundations. Rails bent.
Few, if any (masonry) structures remain standing. Bridges destroyed. Rails bent greatly.
Damage total. Lines of sight and level are distorted. Objects thrown into the air.

pageData.altText: Figure 9: An earthquake nomogram, which shows 3 columns of data: the left column marks the distance (km) and the S-P time (seconds). The right column marks the amplitude (mm). The middle column is the intersection in which the 2 points meet, which marks the magnitude of the event.

tableData.text: Often felt, but rarely causes damage
Noticeable shaking of indoor items, rattling noises. Significant damage unlikely.
Can cause major damage to poorly constructed buildings over small regions. At most slight damage to well-designed buildings.
Can be destructive in areas up to about 160 km (99 mi) across in populated areas
Can cause serious damage over larger areas
Can cause serious damage in areas several hundred km across
Devastating in areas several thousand km across
Never recorded; widespread devastation across very large areas
Considerable to serious damage to buildings; railroad tracks bent
Felt by all, with slight building damage
Felt by some to felt by many

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for activities 1 and 2 of this investigation. Before beginning, you will download Google Earth Pro. In activity 1, you will cut and tape sandpaper strips to form the bottom plate. Then, you will assemble cardboard, sandpaper and rubber bands to form the top plate. Next, you will set up the sandpaper tectonic plates. Then, you will pull the top plate along the bottom plate and observe their interaction. Next, you will add washers to the top plate and observe the movement. Then, you will measure how far the rubber bands can stretch before the plate moves. You will repeat this for 4 trials and test 0, 8 and 16 washers on top of the top plate. In activity 2, you will print out the earthquake data points and world map. Then, you will plot the earthquakes onto the map and photograph it. Next, you will open the IRIS earthquake browser and generate a map of earthquakes. Finally, you will compare the maps before proceeding to activity 3.

A map of the procedural workflow for activity 3 of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, you will identify the P and S waves on a seismogram and calculate the S-P time. Then, you will print out the nomogram, mark the S-P time and amplitude, and connect the lines. Next, you will determine the magnitude of the earthquake. Then, you will open Google Earth Pro and search for a city from a given list. Next, you will use the ruler tool and the given data to approximate the location of the epicenter of the earthquake. Once you have done this for all cities listed, triangulate the latitude and longitude of the earthquake’s epicenter.
Figure 10: Two rectangular pieces of sandpaper (coarse side up) taped together to form a 4.5 x 22” strip. All outer edges and corners are taped down onto a level surface.

Figure 11: A rectangular piece of coarse sandpaper taped on top of a slightly larger piece of cardboard. On the left side of the cardboard there is a hole punched with a rubber band looped through it.

pageData.content: Figure 12. Rubber band chain attached to sandpaper cardboard
pageData.altText: Figure 12: Close-up view of a piece of carboard with a small hole punched in the middle. There is a rubber band tied though the hole, with a second one tied to it, forming a chain.

Figure 13: A rectangular piece of sandpaper and a slightly smaller piece of cardboard, both taped to a flat surface. The piece of cardboard is on the right side, slightly overlapping the sandpaper. There are 8 washers stacked on top of the carboard. There is also a small hole punched through the cardboard with a thick rubber band looped through; a second, thinner rubber band is looped through the thick one.

pageData.content: Figure 14. Washers on sandpaper cardboard with ruler
pageData.altText: Figure 14: A rectangular piece of sandpaper and a slightly smaller piece of cardboard, both taped to a flat surface. The piece of cardboard is on the right side, slightly overlapping the sandpaper. There are 8 washers stacked on top of the carboard. There is also a small hole punched through the cardboard with a thick rubber band looped through; a second, thinner rubber band is looped through the thick one. A 12” plastic ruler is resting directly above the sandpaper.
Figure 15: An Earthquake seismogram

data.title: Active fault
data.content: A fault that has been observed moving, or there is evidence of seismic activity, in the last 10,000 years

data.title: Aftershock
data.content: A release of energy that occurs after the main earthquake;  these quakes are typically weaker than the main earthquake

data.title: Asthenosphere
data.content: The upper layer of Earth's mantle, below the the lithosphere, in which there is relatively low resistance to plastic flow and convection is thought to occur

data.title: Body wave
data.content: A wave of energy released during an earthquake that can travel in three dimensions and move through the interior of the earth

data.title: Convergent plate boundary
data.content: A tectonic boundary where two plates move toward each other, or converge

data.title: Divergent plate boundary
data.content: A tectonic boundary where two plates are moving away from each other and new crust forms from magma that rises to Earth's surface between the two plates

data.title: Elastic rebound theory
data.content: An explanation for how energy is spread during an earthquake

data.title: Epicenter
data.content: The location on the earth's surface directly above the hypocenter (or focus)

data.title: Fault
data.content: An extended break in a body of rock, marked by the relative displacement and discontinuity of strata on either side of a particular surface

data.title: Focus
data.content: The location beneath the earth's surface where the energy was released from the plates colliding and releasing energy; also known as the hypocenter

data.title: Footwall
data.content: The block of rock that lies on the underside of an inclined fault

data.title: Foreshock
data.content: A release of energy that causes a small quake before the main earthquake

data.title: Hanging wall
data.content: The block of rock that lies above and inclined fault

data.title: Hypocenter
data.content: See Focus

data.title: Inactive fault
data.content: A break in the earth's surface in which there is no geologic activity

data.title: Lithosphere
data.content: The rigid outer part of Earth consisting of the crust and upper mantle

data.title: Modified Mercalli Intensity Scale
data.content: A seismic intensity scale used to measure the intensity of shaking from an earthquake

data.title: Moment Magnitude Scale
data.content: A numerical scale that measures all the energy released on the entire fault surface

data.title: Primary wave (P-wave)
data.content: A type of body wave produced by earthquakes; it is the fastest traveling wave in an earthquake, the first to be measured, and it can travel through all substances (solids, liquids and gas)

data.title: Reverse fault
data.content: The opposite of a normal fault; in a reverse fault the hanging wall moves upwards relative to the footwall

data.title: Richter Scale
data.content: A numerical scale for expressing the magnitude of an earthquake on the basis of seismograph oscillations

data.title: Secondary wave (S-wave)
data.content: A type of body wave produced by earthquakes; it arrives after a P-wave but usually with a higher amplitude and can only travel through solids

data.title: Seismic wave
data.content: A vibration from the release of energy during the earthquake

data.title: Seismogram
data.content: A record produced by a seismograph

data.title: Seismograph
data.content: An instrument that measures and records details of earthquakes, such as force and duration

data.title: Seismologist
data.content: A scientist who studies earthquakes and the mechanical characteristics of Earth

data.title: Seismology
data.content: The branch of science concerend with earthquakes and related phenomena

data.title: Strike-slip fault
data.content: A fault in which rock strata are displaced mainly in a horizontal direction, parallel to the line of the fault

data.title: Surface wave
data.content: This type of wave is most associated with the movement of the ground; also known as shaking waves

data.title: Tectonic plate
data.content: A massive, irregularly shaped slab of solid rock composed of both continental and oceanic lithosphere

data.title: Thrust fault
data.content: A reverse fault that dips less than 45 degrees

data.title: Transform plate boundary
data.content: A tectonic boundary where two plates move past one another horizontally

data.title: Triangulation
data.content: A method utilized by seismologists to pinpoint the location of the epicenter of an earthquake by using seismographs taken from a minimum of three different locations
